case.name: SZIWJ v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs [2006] FCA 1706 (27 November 2006)

citphrases.citphrase: tribunal had regard to information from lonely planet guide in rejecting aspect of appellant's claim
whether failure to provide appellant with opportunity to comment upon information constituted breach of s 424a of migration act 1958 (cth)
whether information "the reason, or a part of the reason" for affirming decision under review
point raised on appeal having previously been abandoned at first instance
whether leave to rely upon proposed ground should be granted words & phrases
"the reason, or a part of the reason"
exercise of discretion by appellate court
ground of appeal added by amendment
effect of seeking new trial on different issue
review of refugee review tribunal decision
refusal of a protection (class xa) visa
review of refugee review tribunal decision
applicant a child claiming persecution in fiji on the basis of his mother's gender, race and religion
failure by the tribunal to consider the cumulative impact of those elements of the claim of persecution

citances.sentence: In support of the contention that the Tribunal "considered the evidence as a whole", Mr Potts referred to SZIWJ v Minister for Immigration & Multicultural Affairs [2006] FCA 1706 at [31] - [37] per Jacobson J: [31] The appellant relied upon the decision of Moore J in Kaur v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs [2001] FCA 1401. That case was referred to with apparent approval by Finkelstein J in Jegatheeswaran v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (2001) 194 ALR 263 at [48]. Kaur was a case in which it was argued that the tribunal considered each of the facts put forward by the applicant in isolation but failed to consider their cumulative weight.
In SZIWJ v Minister for Immigration [2006] FCA 1706 Jacobson J dealt with the applicant's submission that the Tribunal had failed to consider his claims cumulatively.
